Understanding Minority-Serving Institutions, 91–110. Minority students who find themselves at “minority-serving institutions”—colleges or universities with high minority enrollments—are even less “traditional” than minority students who attend majority institutions. They are less academically prepared, more sensitive to the cost of college, and more dependent on financial aid than their peers at non-MSIs, and, in the case of Hispanic students, more resistant to going into debt for a college education; see Walter Recharde Allen et al., Black Undergraduates from Bakke to Grutter: Freshman Status, Trends and Prospects, 1971–2004
